body: Forgot my own vote for +1 - that's 3 - I'll get this merged.

Aha - this is failing without the line breaks! Switched back to master and still get:

``` text
 * source:   /home/smallette/git/apache/incubator-tinkerpop/docs/src/the-traversal.asciidoc
   target:   /home/smallette/git/apache/incubator-tinkerpop/target/postprocess-asciidoc/the-traversal.asciidoc
   progress: [================================================================>                                   ] 64%No such property: keys for class: e
Display stack trace? [yN] g.V().hasLabel('song').out('followedBy').groupCount().by('name').
groovysh_parse: 3: expecting EOF, found ')' @ line 3, column 11.
   f.exists()) f.deleteDir()
```

Anyone know what this is?  please fix in this branch if you know the problem that way we can merge back to master cleanly.

Reviewed the code. Tested with and without EPOLL on Linux, tested on non-Linux platforms also.

Giraph hasn't changed since the update to 2.0 Hadoop.

I've run these tests locally when I added the code that I did in this branch.  `SimpleClient` is a wreck in this kind of test case, but not much we can do about that for now. Hopefully we can get some improvements there at some point to simplify that test a bit.

It just occurred to me that we don't need a VOTE here.  This is a PR to a branch that is not a "release" branch - I can just merge this.  Then I will make the PR to master where we will need a VOTE.

SIDENOTE: Daniel, the quantum Gremlin stuff is proving some practical results where I think wave dynamics + your `NumberHelper` work, we will be able to do exclusive or, and, disjoint union, etc. without using memory structures! 3.2.0 is going to get nasty.

VOTE +1.

Seems you always return a Double for `mean().`

```
gremlin> g.V().values('age').mean()
==>30.75
gremlin> __(2,2,4,4).mean()
==>3.0
```

Why is the MeanGlobalStep signature then <Number> ?

Added in some documentation for this and an explicit list of allowable properties, the ascii doc looks ok in my IDEA preview, is there a way to build the docs and view them locally? I'd hate to break them again @okram  :(

I reviewed the code and it looked good. It doesn't touch anything that anyone else works on so its an island unto @dkuppitz world and thus, safe from my perspective. If Kuppitz is happy with the work and test pass. Good.

I see the +1 from @okram above followed by a question and some more commits....is this still good for review or is there more work to do?

@RussellSpitzer if your docs don't contain code examples you can typically get away with:

``` text
bin/process-docs.sh --dryRun
```

which just runs the asciidoc processor.  To see code examples generated too with output you gotta have all the other infrastructure running (i.e. hadoop, etc.).  In your case the `--dryRun` would seem sufficient.
This is good to go. I found a bug that @dkuppitz has since fixed and wrote a test case for.

I couldn't really test this as `mvn clean install` fails for me with :  `InputRDDTest.shouldReadFromArbitraryRDD:51 » IllegalState org.apache.spark.Spa...`
(`spark-gremlin` project)
Am I the only one with this issue?

That failure aside, the docs build correctly and the spark integration tests pass.

This looks good. Nice PR to have. `mvn clean install` passes for me. (minus the weird issues I'm having with spark atm)

VOTE: +1

Tests pass for me as well. it all looks clean. 

VOTE: +1

> Is there any change required to the reference docs?

Yes, I thought about it last night. I will add a comment in the docs, since users now have to ensure that a custom `BulkLoader` implementation uses things like `g.addV()` instead of `graph.addVertex()`, otherwise the `EventStrategy` would be blind and assume that nothing has ever been created. It wouldn't break aything, but it would prevent BLVP from using the optimizations.

I guess there is no way to enforce that the custom `BulkLoader` implementation would use a `TraversalSource` instead of `Graph`.  That's definitely something `BulkLoader` javadocs and reference docs should have especially if it isn't cleanly enforced.

Ok sorry about the delay with this. It took me some time to wrap my head around the StandardStructureTestSuit and adding my crappy testing env to that suddenly made things way more complicated.

Anyways I've tested this with : 

```
mvn clean install -DincludeNeo4j
```

And I've also run related integration tests (though not all as my poor ubuntu VM wouldn't manage.. I'm going to fix the builds on my mac this weekend to have a clean dev environment and avoid this in the future)

I haven't managed to run the tests against titan though (for the threaded transactions) If someone could give those a look it would perfect. Normally the tests should be properly written.

Thanks!!

I intend to improve it by convert some part in groovy and add testing in as many part as it is possible(I have not forgot your feedback). However things had happened after this pull request and I did not have find any time to do all those I had planned to. Of course do not hesitate to tell me if you have any new ideas.

I've recast this work under this PR #140 - no need for any more votes on this one.  @PommeVerte can you please close this one on your end?

Code looks clean, the documentation reflects all the changes. Look all good for me.

Tests all pass as well.

VOTE: +1

I'm really liking the structure here. Thought it was clever to add all of those tutorials in a row like this. No need for an index. 

As far as the implementation goes I'm guessing this means new tutorials will require configuring `sourceDocumentName`?  I don't really remember everything that came out of the discussions around the folder structure for these but I'm guessing this is preferable to a "drop in" solution? 
I'm ok with this either way so my VOTE is +1
VOTE: +1

Yep, looks good to me, too.

VOTE: +1, can be merged

I didn't go through all of it in every little detail, but - although it looks like it would take the reader more than 30 minutes - I like the structure.

VOTE: +1

Thanks for working on this. I see you did something for reading a graph, but what about writing?

https://github.com/kushal256/incubator-tinkerpop/blob/master/tinkergraph-gremlin/src/main/java/org/apache/tinkerpop/gremlin/tinkergraph/structure/TinkerGraph.java#L296

Note that the docs needed to be updated:

https://github.com/apache/incubator-tinkerpop/blob/master/docs/src/implementations.asciidoc#configuration

Specifically, the configuration description for `gremlin.tinkergraph.graphFormat` needs something to denote this new feature.  

Would be nice to see a test case as well.  Perhaps you could stub a reader/writer and assert that the class gets created and the appropriate methods are called. wdyt?

I'm not sure how others  feel, but I think we will wait to merge this until after release of 3.1.0-incubating (in code freeze for that now).
I agree, I'd also like to see that covered by one or two tests.

Nice and solid code.

VOTE: +1

Like the changes. This looks nice.
Tests pass.
Definite +1 from me.

@dkuppitz it depends on how you wan to measure the minutes.  in pure "reading" time, this is under 30 minutes.  "comprehension" time, trying all the examples, etc. - that's probably over 30 minutes.  i was shooting for "reading" time (which i've tested)

Thanks for your comments.  Yes, there should be similar logic for writing
graph.

Also, I agree, there should be tests, but I'm not sure how to do so when
using reflection (Class.forName() and newInstance() for creating new
Io.Builder), with mockito's stubs.  Any recommendations for how to do this?
On Nov 9, 2015 4:13 AM, "Daniel Kuppitz" notifications@github.com wrote:

> I agree, I'd also like to see that covered by one or two tests.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/incubator-tinkerpop/pull/141#issuecomment-155047954
> .
Don't use mockito.  Create your mock the old fashioned way and just create a concrete class in test that implements the interfaces you need.
OK just checked in with an old fashioned mock.
This fixed a minor bug and added some good test coverage.  Fairly trivial code wise.  Merged via CTR.  Thanks
+1 ... this should have been a CTR. This is wasting people's time/effort.

i'm really don't agree - during code freeze, all commits should be under scrutiny. outside of code freeze i would have CTR'd.  also, i don't think anyone who wants a review should feel reticent to ask for one in or out of code freeze regardless of complexity.
